name: Russian knapweed
notes: Limited distribution but spreads rapidly. Requires immediate eradication.

name: False brome
notes: Limited distribution but can quickly form monocultures in forest habitats.

name: Italian and slender flowered thistle
notes: Two related species with limited distribution that can rapidly dominate grassland areas.

name: Drooping Sedge
notes: Can dominate wet forest understories.

name: Jubata grass
notes: Similar to pampas grass, with limited distribution but aggressive spread potential.

name: Paterson's curse
notes: Limited distribution but can rapidly invade grassland habitats.

name: Giant hogweed
notes: Limited distribution but extremely harmful - sap can cause severe skin burns. Requires immediate control.

name: Orange hawkweed
notes: Limited distribution but can spread rapidly and form dense mats.

name: Meadow hawkweed
notes: Limited distribution but can rapidly colonize open habitats.

name: Policemen's helmet
notes: Limited distribution but can quickly dominate riparian areas and moist forests.

name: Yellow archangel
notes: Can form dense mats in forest understories.

name: Water primrose
notes: Can form dense mats that choke waterways.

name: Scotch thistle
notes: Limited distribution but can form dense stands in open areas.

name: Harding grass
notes: Can form dense stands that exclude native grasses.

name: Common reed
notes: Limited distribution but can form dense stands in wetland habitats.

name: Pokeweed
notes: Produces toxic berries and can persist for many years.

name: Kudzu
notes: Limited distribution but can grow extremely rapidly and smother trees and infrastructure.

name: Blessed milk thistle
notes: Limited distribution but can form dense patches.

name: Salt cedar
notes: Limited distribution but can alter hydrology and increase soil salinity.

name: Gorse
notes: Limited distribution but forms impenetrable spiny thickets.

name: Swollen bladderwort
notes: Can form dense mats in freshwater habitats.

name: Tall verbena
notes: Can spread rapidly in open areas.

name: Velvetleaf
notes: Herbaceous plant that can spread rapidly and is difficult to control once widespread.

name: Norway maple
notes: Can outcompete native maples and other forest species.

name: Tree-of-heaven
notes: Fast-growing with allelopathic properties that inhibit growth of other plants.

name: Garlic mustard
notes: Biennial that spreads rapidly in forest understories.

name: Three-corner leek
notes: Bulbous perennial that can form dense patches.

name: Indigo bush
notes: Can form thickets along waterways.

name: Italian arum
notes: Also known as cuckoo pint. Difficult to eradicate due to persistent tubers.

name: Butterfly bush
notes: Produces many seeds that can establish in natural areas.

name: Diffuse knapweed
notes: Can form monocultures in grassland habitats.

name: Spotted knapweed
notes: Produces allelopathic compounds that inhibit other plants.

name: Celandine
notes: Produces orange sap and can form dense colonies.

name: Rush skeletonweed
notes: Deep taproot makes control difficult.

name: Spurge laurel
notes: Evergreen that can thrive in deep shade.

name: South American waterweed
notes: Can form dense mats that choke waterways.

name: Oblong spurge
notes: Also known as eggleaf spurge. Contains toxic sap.

name: Bohemian knotweed
notes: Hybrid between Japanese and giant knotweed with aggressive growth.

name: Goat's Rue
notes: Forms dense stands and is toxic to livestock.

name: Smooth hawkweed
notes: Can form dense patches that exclude native vegetation.

name: Mouse-ear hawkweed
notes: Spreads by stolons and forms dense mats.

name: Common hawkweed
notes: Can dominate grassland habitats.

name: Yellow flag
notes: Forms dense colonies in wetland habitats.

name: European soft rush
notes: Can form dense stands in wet areas.

name: Dalmation toadflax
notes: Deep root system makes control difficult.

name: Floating water primrose
notes: Can form dense mats on water surfaces.

name: Money plant
notes: Garden escape that can form patches in natural areas.

name: Spatula leaf purslane
notes: Can colonize areas with fluctuating water levels.

name: Purple loosestrife
notes: Can form monocultures in wetland habitats.

name: Parrots feather
notes: Forms dense mats both below and above water surface.

name: Evergreen bugloss
notes: Can form patches in woodland habitats.

name: Climbing bindweed
notes: Can climb and smother other vegetation.

name: Japanese knotweed
notes: Aggressive growth with extensive rhizome system.

name: Himalayan knotweed
notes: Forms dense stands in moist habitats.

name: Giant knotweed
notes: Can grow to over 10 feet tall with extensive root system.

name: White poplar
notes: Spreads aggressively through root suckers.

name: Lesser celandine
notes: Forms dense carpets in early spring that exclude native vegetation.

name: Garden nightshade
notes: Produces toxic berries and can spread in cultivated areas.

name: Guelder rose
notes: Can form thickets in natural areas.

name: Sycamore maple
notes: Widely distributed and abundant throughout the region.

name: Horse chestnut
notes: Widespread ornamental that can establish in natural areas.

name: Common burdock
notes: Forms burrs that stick to clothing and animal fur.

name: Tall oatgrass
notes: Can dominate grassland communities.

name: Cutleaf birch
notes: Can establish in natural areas from landscape plantings.

name: Cheatgrass
notes: Annual grass that increases fire risk in dry areas.

name: Pond water starwort
notes: Forms mats in shallow water bodies.

name: Lady's-nightcap
notes: Can climb and smother native vegetation.

name: Meadow knapweed
notes: Hybrid knapweed that can dominate grasslands.

name: Canada thistle
notes: Widespread with deep rhizomes making control difficult.

name: Common thistle
notes: Biennial thistle with sharp spines.

name: Traveler's joy
notes: Can climb and smother trees in woodlands.

name: Poison-hemlock
notes: Highly toxic biennial that can form dense stands.

name: Field morning-glory
notes: Persistent deep roots make control difficult.

name: English hawthorn
notes: Forms thickets and can alter forest structure.

name: Scotch broom
notes: Forms dense stands that exclude native vegetation.

name: Queen Anne's lace
notes: Widespread in open areas.

name: Common teasel
notes: Forms dense stands in open areas.

name: Broad-leaved helleborine
notes: Orchid that can thrive in disturbed forest understories.

name: Fennel
notes: Forms dense stands in open areas.

name: Shining geranium
notes: Forms carpet-like patches in forests.

name: Robert geranium
notes: Also known as herb-robert, can form dense patches.

name: European avens
notes: Can form patches in forest understories.

name: English ivy
notes: Climbs trees and forms dense ground cover.

name: Irish ivy
notes: Similar to English ivy but more vigorous.

name: St. John's wort
notes: Forms dense stands in open areas.

name: Spotted cat's ear
notes: Common in lawns and meadows.

name: English holly
notes: Can form dense thickets in forest understories.

name: Spotted touch-me-not
notes: Annual that can form dense patches in wet areas.

name: Prickly lettuce
notes: Common annual weed in disturbed areas.

name: Nipplewort
notes: Annual that can spread in disturbed areas.

name: Oxeye daisy
notes: Forms patches in open areas.

name: Privet
notes: Can form dense thickets.

name: Bird's foot trefoil
notes: Forms patches in open areas.

name: Sweetclover
notes: Tall biennial that can dominate open areas.

name: Lemon balm
notes: Aromatic mint that can escape cultivation.

name: Pennyroyal
notes: Aromatic mint that can form patches in wet areas.

name: Eurasian watermilfoil
notes: Forms dense mats that can choke waterways.

name: Fragrant water lily
notes: Forms dense surface coverage on water bodies.

name: Yellow glandweed
notes: Annual that can form patches in wet areas.

name: Reed canarygrass
notes: Forms dense monocultures in wetland habitats.

name: Curly-leaf pondweed
notes: Forms dense underwater growth in water bodies.

name: Sulphur cinquefoil
notes: Forms patches in open areas.

name: Sweet cherry
notes: Can establish in natural areas from bird-dispersed seeds.

name: English laurel
notes: Evergreen that can form dense stands in forest understories.

name: Portuguese laurel
notes: Evergreen that can establish in natural areas.

name: Double-flowered creeping buttercup
notes: Spreads by runners and forms dense patches.

name: Black locust
notes: Spreads aggressively through root suckers.

name: Sweetbriar rose
notes: Forms thorny thickets.

name: Multiflora rose
notes: Forms dense thorny thickets.

name: Himalayan blackberry
notes: Forms impenetrable thorny thickets.

name: Evergreen blackberry
notes: Forms thorny thickets with cut-leaf foliage.

name: Ragwort
notes: Toxic to livestock and spreads readily.

name: Rose campion
notes: Garden escape that can spread in natural areas.

name: Hedge mustard
notes: Common in disturbed areas.

name: Bittersweet nightshade
notes: Produces toxic berries and can climb vegetation.

name: Sowthistles
latinName: Sonchus arvensis, S. asper, and S. oleraceus
notes: Group of related species common in disturbed areas.

name: Medusahead
notes: Annual grass that increases fire risk.

name: Common tansy
notes: Forms dense stands in open areas.

name: Hare's foot clover
notes: Annual that can form patches in open areas.

name: Red clover
notes: Common in grassland habitats.

name: White clover
notes: Common in lawns and other grassy areas.

name: Subterraneum clover
notes: Buries its seedpods in the soil.

name: Moth mullein
notes: Biennial that can spread in open areas.

name: Common mullein
notes: Biennial with woolly leaves that colonizes disturbed sites.

name: Tufted vetch
notes: Climbing vine that can smother other vegetation.

name: Hairy vetch
notes: Annual or biennial climbing vine.

name: Periwinkle (large leaf)
notes: Spreading groundcover that can form dense mats.

name: Periwinkle (small leaf)
notes: Spreading groundcover that excludes native vegetation.

name: Goutweed
notes: Garden escape that can spread in shady areas.

name: Redtop bentgrass
notes: Common grass in moist habitats.

name: Colonial bentgrass
notes: Commonly used in lawns and persists in natural areas.

name: Creeping bentgrass
notes: Forms dense mats in wet areas.

name: Meadow foxtail
notes: Perennial grass that can persist in meadows.

name: Sweet vernalgrass
notes: Fragrant grass common in meadows.

name: Ripgut brome
notes: Annual grass with sharp awns.

name: Chicory
notes: Perennial with blue flowers that persists in disturbed areas.

name: Quackgrass
notes: Persistent grass with rhizomes that can spread in cultivated areas.

name: Mole plant
notes: Garden escape with toxic sap.

name: Velvet grass
notes: Soft, hairy grass common in meadows.

name: Chameleon plant
notes: Variegated garden plant that can spread in moist areas.

name: Yellow toadflax
notes: Perennial with yellow snapdragon-like flowers.

name: Annual ryegrass
notes: Common grass used for temporary lawns and erosion control.

name: Perennial ryegrass
notes: Common turf grass that can persist in natural areas.

name: Greater bird's foot trefoil
notes: Legume that can form patches in wet areas.

name: Wall lettuce
notes: Woodland plant that can spread in shady areas.

name: Timothy
notes: Common forage grass that persists in meadows.

name: Annual bluegrass
notes: Common lawn weed that can establish in many habitats.

name: Tall buttercup
notes: Yellow-flowered perennial common in meadows.

name: European watercress
notes: Edible aquatic plant that can form mats in streams.

name: Tall fescue
notes: Robust grass commonly planted for forage and erosion control.

name: Cultivated rye
notes: Grain crop that can persist after cultivation.

name: White campion
notes: White-flowered biennial or short-lived perennial.

name: European mountain ash
notes: Ornamental tree that can establish from bird-dispersed seeds.

name: Siberian elm
notes: Fast-growing tree that can establish in disturbed areas.

name: Common bladderwort
notes: Carnivorous aquatic plant that can form patches in still water.

name: Common vetch
notes: Nitrogen-fixing legume often used as a cover crop.

name: Porcelainberry
notes: Vine with colorful berries; can climb and smother vegetation.

name: Canebreak bamboo
notes: Native to southeastern US; can form dense stands.

name: Spotted laurel
notes: Evergreen shrub with spotted leaves; bird-dispersed seeds.

name: Flowering rush
notes: Emergent aquatic plant that can alter wetland habitats.

name: White top
notes: Also known as hoary cress; spreads by roots and seeds.

name: Plumeless thistle
notes: Spiny biennial that can form dense stands.

name: Musk thistle
notes: Nodding purple flower heads; prolific seed producer.

name: Purple starthistle
notes: Spiny thistle-like plant with purple flowers.

name: Iberian starthistle
notes: Similar to purple starthistle with different spine patterns.

name: Brown knapweed
notes: Perennial knapweed with brown-edged bracts.

name: Yellow starthistle
notes: Spiny annual with yellow flowers; can form monocultures.

name: Pampas grass
notes: Large ornamental grass with showy plumes; spreads by seed.

name: Montbretia
notes: Orange-flowered garden plant that spreads by corms.

name: French broom
notes: Similar to Scotch broom but with different leaf pattern.

name: Portugese broom
notes: Broom species with ridged stems and hairy seed pods.

name: Leafy spurge
notes: Deep-rooted perennial with toxic sap; difficult to control.

name: Sweet woodruff
notes: Fragrant groundcover that can spread in shaded areas.

name: Hydrilla
notes: Submersed aquatic plant that can form dense mats.

name: Golden chain tree
notes: Ornamental with hanging yellow flowers; all parts toxic.

name: White nancy
notes: Variegated deadnettle that can spread in shaded areas.

name: Perennial peavine
notes: Climbing vine with pink flowers; can smother vegetation.

name: Creeping jenny
notes: Creeping groundcover that can form mats in moist areas.

name: Yellow sweetclover
notes: Tall biennial with yellow flowers; nitrogen fixer.

name: Yellow floatingheart
notes: Aquatic plant with heart-shaped floating leaves.

name: Virginia creeper
notes: Climbing vine with five leaflets; can cover trees.

name: Princess tree
notes: Fast-growing tree with purple flowers; prolific seeder.

name: Sweet coltsfoot
notes: Large-leaved plant that spreads by rhizomes.

name: Incense bamboo
notes: Running bamboo that can spread aggressively by rhizomes.

name: Water bamboo
notes: Bamboo species that tolerates wet conditions.

name: Big-node bamboo
notes: Running bamboo with distinctive swollen nodes.

name: Broadleaf bamboo
notes: Low-growing bamboo with large leaves; spreads by rhizomes.

name: Kuma bamboo
notes: Bamboo with white-edged leaves in winter; spreads by rhizomes.

name: Hairy nightshade
notes: Annual with small white flowers and hairy foliage.

name: Johnson grass
notes: Tall grass with robust rhizomes; can be toxic to livestock.

name: Alsike clover
notes: Pink to white flowered clover used in pastures.

name: Bigleaf Maple
notes: Large deciduous tree with expansive crown. Important component of mixed conifer-deciduous forests.

name: Red Alder
notes: Fast-growing deciduous tree. Nitrogen fixer that helps rebuild soil fertility in disturbed areas.

name: Douglas Fir
notes: Dominant conifer in western forests. Can grow to enormous size and great age.

name: Western Red Cedar
notes: Large conifer with flattened sprays of scale-like foliage. Prefers moist conditions and can tolerate shade.

name: Western Hemlock
notes: Shade-tolerant conifer with drooping leader. Often indicates mature forest conditions.

name: Grand Fir
notes: Tall conifer with flattened needles in two distinct rows. Prefers moist, rich soils.

name: Western Flowering Dogwood
notes: Small understory tree with showy white bracts in spring and red fruit in fall.

name: Cascara
notes: Also known as chitum. Small tree with distinctive bark and berries that turn from red to black.

name: Oregon Ash
notes: Deciduous tree often found in seasonally flooded areas.

name: Black Cottonwood
notes: Fast-growing deciduous tree that can reach large sizes. Important in riparian ecosystems.

name: Bitter Cherry
notes: Small tree with white flowers and small red cherries. Provides food for wildlife.

name: Scouler Willow
notes: Upland willow species that can grow as a large shrub or small tree.

name: Pacific Yew
notes: Slow-growing conifer with flat needles and red arils instead of cones. Tolerates deep shade.

name: Madrone
notes: Evergreen broadleaf tree with distinctive reddish peeling bark. Prefers drier conditions.

name: Suksdorf's hawthorn
notes: Small thorny tree with white flowers and red fruits. Important for wildlife.

name: Willamette Valley ponderosa pine
notes: Regional variety of ponderosa pine adapted to valley conditions. Tolerates drier sites.

name: Oregon White Oak
notes: Deciduous oak that forms savanna habitats. Important for wildlife and supports high biodiversity.

name: Vine Maple
notes: Multi-stemmed deciduous shrub with bright fall color. Grows in clumps in forest understory.

name: Western Serviceberry
notes: Multi-stemmed shrub with white spring flowers and edible purple berries. Important wildlife food.

name: Cascade Oregon Grape
notes: Low-growing evergreen shrub with holly-like leaves and yellow flowers. Produces blue-black berries.

name: California hazelnut
notes: Deciduous shrub that produces edible nuts in distinctive husks. Important wildlife food.

name: Redosier dogwood
notes: Deciduous shrub with bright red stems in winter. Grows in wet areas and along streams.

name: Salal
notes: Evergreen shrub with leathery leaves and edible black berries. Forms dense patches in forest understory.

name: Oceanspray
notes: Deciduous shrub with cascades of white flowers in summer. Adapts to a variety of conditions.

name: Indian Plum
notes: One of the earliest shrubs to leaf out and flower in spring. Produces small plum-like fruits.

name: Pacific Ninebark
notes: Deciduous shrub with peeling bark and clusters of white flowers. Prefers moist areas.

name: Red Currant
notes: Deciduous shrub with showy pink to red flower clusters in early spring. Produces dark berries.

name: Thimbleberry
notes: Deciduous shrub with large maple-like leaves and white flowers. Produces edible red berries.

name: Salmonberry
notes: Deciduous shrub with pink flowers and salmon-colored to red berries. Common in wet areas.

name: Red Elderberry
notes: Large deciduous shrub with compound leaves and pyramids of white flowers. Produces bright red berries.

name: Common Snowberry
notes: Deciduous shrub with distinctive white berries that persist into winter. Spreads by suckers.

name: Red Huckleberry
notes: Deciduous shrub with bright green angular branches. Produces tart red berries appreciated by wildlife and humans.

name: Tall Oregon Grape
notes: Evergreen shrub with holly-like leaves and yellow flowers. Taller than Cascade Oregon grape.

name: Western Wahoo
notes: Deciduous shrub with inconspicuous flowers but distinctive pink fruit capsules that split to reveal orange seeds.

name: Hairy Honeysuckle
notes: Climbing or trailing vine-like shrub with pink tubular flowers. Produces red berries.

name: Black Twinberry
notes: Deciduous shrub with yellow tubular flowers surrounded by red bracts. Produces paired black berries.

name: Western Crabapple
notes: Small tree or large shrub with white to pink flowers. Produces small tart apples.

name: Mockorange
notes: Deciduous shrub with fragrant white flowers. Prefers well-drained sites.

name: Common Chokecherry
notes: Deciduous shrub or small tree with elongated clusters of white flowers. Produces astringent dark fruits.

name: Sticky Currant
notes: Deciduous shrub with sticky glandular hairs on leaves and stems. Produces blue-black berries.

name: Baldhip Rose
notes: Delicate wild rose with small single pink flowers. Produces small smooth rose hips.

name: Nootka Rose
notes: Sturdy wild rose with large pink flowers and prominent thorns. Produces large rose hips.

name: Swamp Rose
notes: Wild rose adapted to wet habitats. Produces clusters of pink flowers and small round hips.

name: Pacific blackberry
notes: Native trailing blackberry with small, sweet berries. Less aggressive than invasive blackberry species.

name: Sitka Willow
notes: Deciduous shrub with distinctive silvery undersides to leaves. Grows along waterways.

name: Blue Elderberry
notes: Large deciduous shrub with flat-topped clusters of white flowers. Produces blue berries with a whitish bloom.

name: Creeping Snowberry
notes: Low-growing trailing form of snowberry. Produces white berries similar to common snowberry.

name: Oval-leaved Viburnum
notes: Deciduous shrub with flat-topped clusters of white flowers. Produces black berries.

name: Oregon Tea-tree
notes: Deciduous shrub with clusters of small white flowers. Nitrogen fixer that grows in drier habitats.

name: Mountain Balm
notes: Evergreen shrub with glossy aromatic leaves and clusters of white flowers. Adapted to dry conditions.

name: Blue Currant
notes: Deciduous shrub with maple-like leaves and elongated clusters of flowers. Produces blue-black berries with a white bloom.

name: Straggly Gooseberry
notes: Spiny deciduous shrub with nodding greenish-purple flowers. Produces dark purple edible berries.

name: Pioneer Gooseberry
notes: Spiny deciduous shrub with distinctive fuchsia-like flowers. Produces bristly berries.

name: Blackcap Raspberry
notes: Deciduous shrub with whitish stems and compound leaves. Produces sweet black raspberries.

name: Evergreen Huckleberry
notes: Evergreen shrub with small leathery leaves and pinkish bell-shaped flowers. Produces shiny black berries.

name: Vanillaleaf
notes: Distinctive three-part leaves that emit vanilla scent when dried. Forms colonies in deep forest shade.

name: Northern Maidenhair Fern
notes: Delicate fern with black stems and fan-shaped leaflets. Prefers moist, sheltered locations.

name: Wild Ginger
notes: Heart-shaped evergreen leaves with hidden maroon flowers at ground level. Has ginger-like aroma.

name: Lady Fern
notes: Large, lacy fern with feathery fronds that form clumps. Thrives in moist environments.

name: Slender-foot sedge
notes: Fine-textured woodland sedge with slender stems and delicate seed heads.

name: Miner's Lettuce
location: Moist, shaded areas, often in disturbed sites
notes: Annual with distinctive round leaves that encircle the stem. Edible with mild flavor.

name: Candy Flower
notes: Delicate pink to white flowers with distinct veining. Commonly found in moist forest settings.

name: Bleedingheart
notes: Distinctive heart-shaped pink flowers hanging from arching stems above ferny foliage.

name: Blue Wildrye
notes: Native perennial bunchgrass with blue-green foliage. Adapts to various light conditions.

name: Cleavers
notes: Annual with sticky stems and leaves that cling to clothing and fur. Also known as bedstraw.

name: Pacific Waterleaf
notes: Woodland perennial with deeply lobed leaves and clusters of light purple to white flowers.

name: Twinflower
notes: Trailing evergreen groundcover with pairs of nodding pink bell-shaped flowers.

name: Western False Solomon's Seal
notes: Arching stems with alternate leaves and plume-like clusters of small white flowers at tip.

name: Starry False Solomon's Seal
notes: Similar to False Solomon's Seal but with star-shaped flowers in a small cluster.

name: Oregon Oxalis
notes: Shamrock-like leaves that fold down in bright light. White to pink flowers. Forms carpets in deep shade.

name: Palmate Coltsfoot
notes: Large palm-shaped leaves emerge after white to pinkish flower clusters. Spreads by rhizomes.

name: Licorice Fern
location: Often on mossy tree trunks, logs, or rocks
notes: Evergreen fern with simple fronds divided into rounded segments. Rhizomes taste like licorice.

name: Sword Fern
notes: Large evergreen fern with leathery, sword-shaped fronds. Dominant groundcover in many PNW forests.

name: Hooker's Fairybells
notes: Forked stems with hanging cream-colored bell-shaped flowers. Produces orange to red berries.

name: Smith's Fairybells
notes: Similar to Hooker's Fairybells but with more pronounced leaf veins and different flower characteristics.

name: Bracken Fern
notes: Tall, triangular fronds on single stems. Spreads aggressively by rhizomes, especially in open areas.

name: Clasping-leaved Twisted-stalk
notes: Arching stems with clasping, alternate leaves. Small greenish-white bell flowers hang beneath the stems.

name: Fringecup
notes: Tall stalks of small, fringed greenish to pink flowers above a basal rosette of maple-like leaves.

name: Trefoil Tiarella
notes: Delicate sprays of small white flowers above maple-like leaves. Also known as foamflower.

name: Piggyback Plant
notes: Named for the plantlets that form at the base of leaf blades. Small brownish-purple flowers.

name: Western Trillium
notes: Three leaves in a whorl topped by a three-petaled white flower that turns pink with age.

name: Inside-out Flower
notes: Delicate, fern-like leaves with small white flowers that appear to be turned inside-out.

name: Stream Violet
notes: Bright yellow flowers with dark veining over heart-shaped leaves. Prefers moist sites.

name: Baneberry
notes: Clusters of white flowers followed by bright red berries on red stalks. All parts are toxic.

name: Pathfinder
notes: Distinctive two-toned leaves, green above and silvery-white below. Named for visibility in dark forests.

name: Large-flowered Agoseris
notes: Dandelion-like yellow flowers on leafless stems rising from a basal rosette of narrow leaves.

name: Western White Anemone
notes: Single white flower with 5 petal-like sepals above a whorl of three leaves.

name: Spreading Dogbane
notes: Spreading stems with pink bell-shaped flowers. Contains milky sap and is related to milkweed.

name: Red Columbine
notes: Distinctive red and yellow flowers with backward-pointing spurs. Attracts hummingbirds.

name: Goatsbeard
notes: Large, fern-like compound leaves with plumes of tiny white flowers. Separate male and female plants.

name: Deer Fern
notes: Evergreen fern with two types of fronds: spreading sterile fronds and upright fertile fronds.

name: California Brome
notes: Native perennial grass with drooping seed heads. Adapts to various light conditions.

name: Scouler's Bellflower
notes: Slender stems with small star-shaped white to blue flowers. Delicate woodland plant.

name: Few-flowered Aster
notes: Woodland aster with lavender to purple ray flowers surrounding yellow disk flowers.

name: Angled Bittercress
notes: Woodland mustard with white to pinkish flowers and compound leaves. Found in wet areas.

name: Bigleaf Sedge
notes: Large sedge with wide leaves and prominent flower/seed heads. Thrives in wet areas.

name: Henderson's Wood Sedge
notes: Woodland sedge with slender stems and nodding seed heads. Adaptable to various light conditions.

name: Fireweed
notes: Tall spikes of magenta flowers in disturbed areas. Among first plants to colonize after fire or clearing.

name: Woodreed
notes: Woodland grass with broad leaves and open, airy seed heads. Tolerates deep shade.

name: Enchanter's nightshade
notes: Delicate woodland plant with small white flowers. Produces small burr-like fruits that stick to clothing.

name: Cutleaf Goldthread
notes: Low evergreen perennial with deeply divided leaves and small white flowers. Has yellow rhizomes.

name: Bunchberry
notes: Low-growing relative of dogwood with four white bracts surrounding tiny flowers. Produces red berries.

name: Western Corydalis
notes: Woodland plant with delicate, fern-like leaves and clusters of pink tubular flowers.

name: Hooker Fairy-bell
notes: Woodland plant with arching stems and creamy bell-shaped flowers beneath leaves. Orange to red berries.

name: Large-flowered Fairy-bell
notes: Similar to Hooker's fairy-bell but with larger flowers and different leaf characteristics.

name: Wood Fern
notes: Evergreen fern with lacy, twice-divided fronds. Also known as coastal wood fern.

name: Spreading Wood Fern
notes: Large, lacy fern with triangular fronds that grow in vase-like clusters.

name: Western Fescue
notes: Fine-textured native bunchgrass adapted to partial shade. Common in drier forest understory.

name: Bearded Fescue
notes: Woodland grass with delicate, nodding seed heads. Adapted to shaded conditions.

name: Wood Strawberry
notes: Low-growing woodland plant with white flowers and small, aromatic red berries.

name: Sweetscented Bedstraw
notes: Woodland plant with whorled leaves and sweet vanilla scent when dried. Less sticky than cleavers.

name: Oregon Avens
notes: Perennial with lobed basal leaves and small yellow flowers. Produces burr-like seed heads.

name: Cow parsnip
notes: Large native umbel with huge leaves and flat-topped white flower clusters. Can cause skin irritation.

name: Smallflowered Alumroot
notes: Evergreen perennial with maple-like leaves and tall sprays of tiny white flowers.

name: White-flowered Hawkweed
notes: Native woodland hawkweed with hairy leaves and white dandelion-like flowers.

name: Oregon Iris
notes: Tough-leaved iris with showy purple to blue flowers. Adapts to dry conditions.

name: Parsley-leaved Lovage
notes: Aromatic perennial with fern-like leaves and umbels of small white flowers.

name: Gray's Lovage
notes: Similar to parsley-leaved lovage but with different leaf characteristics.

name: Columbia Lily
notes: Elegant native lily with nodding orange flowers spotted with maroon. Also called tiger lily.

name: Broadleaf Lupine
notes: Perennial with palmately compound leaves and tall spikes of blue to purple flowers. Nitrogen fixer.

name: Field Woodrush
notes: Grass-like perennial with distinctive flower clusters. Adapted to various light conditions.

name: Small-flowered Woodrush
notes: Delicate woodrush with open, branched clusters of small flowers. Prefers moist conditions.

name: Skunk Cabbage
notes: Large-leaved wetland plant with bright yellow spathe surrounding a fleshy spadix. Strong odor when crushed.

name: False Lily-of-the-valley
notes: Low woodland groundcover with heart-shaped leaves and small white flower clusters. Produces red berries.

name: Western Bluebells
notes: Spring-blooming perennial with nodding clusters of blue bell-shaped flowers.

name: Leafy Mitrewort
notes: Delicate woodland plant with small star-shaped flowers with fringed petals on slender stems.

name: Five-stamened Mitrewort
notes: Similar to leafy mitrewort but with different flower characteristics. Prefers very moist sites.

name: Indian-pipe
notes: Ghostly white plant without chlorophyll. Parasitic on fungi associated with tree roots.

name: Streambank Springbeauty
notes: Delicate perennial with small rosette of leaves and slender stems bearing pink to white flowers.

name: Baby Blue-eyes
notes: Low-growing annual with delicate blue flowers with white centers. Spring bloomer.

name: Devil's Club
notes: Large-leaved shrub-like plant covered with spines. Related to ginseng. Produces bright red berries.

name: Mountain Sweet-Cicely
notes: Woodland plant with fern-like leaves and small white flowers. Seeds have anise-like flavor and aroma.

name: Sticky Cinquefoil
notes: Perennial with compound leaves and small yellow flowers. Stems and leaves have sticky glands.

name: Native Heal-all
notes: Low-growing perennial with square stems and spikes of purple flowers. Has medicinal properties.

name: Wintergreen
notes: Evergreen perennial with round leaves and nodding pink flowers on slender stalks.

name: Yerba Buena
notes: Aromatic trailing groundcover with small white flowers. Has minty fragrance when crushed.

name: Small-fruited Bullrush
notes: Tall wetland sedge with triangular stems and clusters of small brownish flowers/seeds.

name: Cooley's hedgenettle
notes: Square-stemmed mint family plant with whorls of purple flowers. Tolerates partial shade.

name: Douglas's Aster
notes: Late-blooming perennial with purple ray flowers surrounding yellow disk flowers.

name: Western Meadowrue
notes: Delicate woodland plant with fern-like leaves and hanging clusters of small flowers.

name: Foamflower
notes: Delicate woodland perennial with maple-like leaves and airy spikes of small white flowers.

name: Western Starflower
notes: Delicate woodland perennial with a whorl of leaves topped by star-shaped white to pink flowers.

name: Stinging Nettle
notes: Tall perennial with opposite leaves and stinging hairs. Important wildlife food and native fiber plant.

name: Giant Vetch
notes: Climbing legume with compound leaves ending in tendrils. Produces purple flowers and is a nitrogen fixer.

name: Small Wind-flower
notes: Delicate woodland plant with single white flower above a whorl of three leaves.

name: Oregon Anemone
notes: Spring-blooming woodland plant with blue to violet flowers above a whorl of three leaves.

name: Slender Boykinia
notes: Perennial with maple-like leaves and clusters of small white flowers. Prefers very moist habitats.

name: Fairy Slipper
notes: Delicate orchid with single mottled leaf and showy pink flower. Rare and sensitive to disturbance.

name: Pacific Hound's-tongue
notes: Early spring bloomer with large basal leaves and clusters of blue flowers. Seeds stick to fur and clothing.

name: Mountain Lady-slipper
notes: Rare native orchid with white and brown flowers. Sensitive to disturbance and collection.

name: Brittle Bladder Fern
notes: Delicate fern with lacy fronds that often grows on rocks or in rock crevices.

name: Giant Fawn-lily
notes: Spring ephemeral with mottled leaves and nodding white flowers that age to pink.

name: Giant Rattlesnake-plantain
notes: Evergreen orchid with distinctive white-veined leaves and spikes of small white flowers.

name: Oak Fern
notes: Delicate deciduous fern with triangular fronds divided into three main parts.

name: Orange Honeysuckle
notes: Climbing vine with orange tubular flowers attractive to hummingbirds. Native alternative to invasive honeysuckles.

name: Turtle Head
notes: Perennial with opposite leaves and tubular pink flowers resembling a turtle's head.

name: Pacific Sanicle
notes: Woodland plant with palmately lobed leaves and small yellow flowers in dense clusters.

name: Snow Queen
notes: Early spring bloomer with round, scalloped leaves and spikes of blue flowers.

name: Small-flowered trillium
notes: Spring ephemeral with three leaves in a whorl and smaller flowers than typical western trillium.

name: Hall's Violet
notes: Woodland violet with yellow flowers marked with purple streaks on lower petals.

name: Evergreen Violet
notes: Low-growing violet with heart-shaped evergreen leaves and small yellow flowers.
